page.title: 16STRAWPLAITING IN PRESTON
page.content: Strawplaiting was an important feature of village life in rural Preston until the latter part of the 19th century. The extra money earned by the farm_ worker's wife and children raised the standard of living above the average. There were 2 strawplait schools in the village and children of 7 or younger were taught to plait the wheatstraw. Some of the plait was worked with split straw and some with whole.There were many patterns.The completed plaits, in 20 yd lengths, were taken to Hitchin market and the plait buyer would give about 2d for good work.From there the lengths of plait would go to factories in Luton to be made into hats.The art of strawplait has died but the tools_straw splitters and straw mills are to be found in Hitchin Museum.
